Award.AwardTitle: P2C2: Estimating Climate Sensitivity from Temperature Reconstructions of the Last Glacial Maximum
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a project to use paleoclimate reconstructions of the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM: 21,000 years ago) and a variety of climate models to evaluate equilibrium climate sensitivity. Schmittner-Boesch published an influential paper in 2011 suggesting that the geological evidence implied an equilibrium climate sensitivity to a doubling of atmospheric CO2 of 1.4 to 2.8 C, lower than the IPCC4 likely range of 2 to 4.5 C and that the geological data ruled out very high sensitivities to doubling of CO2. However there were several issues left unresolved. For instance, several different paleoclimate reconstructions of the LGM produce different average reductions in global temperatures, which have a big effect of the sensitivity estimates. In addition, the range of error on the paleoclimate reconstructions is large and the effects of this error on the climate sensitivity need to be better quantified. Finally the initial study was performed with a "reduce-complexity" climate model. It was not clear the extent to which the result was affected by choice of model.

This project will further evaluate these issues by expanding the paleoclimate reconstructions used in the study and incorporating the output from fully coupled climate model simulations of the LGM. Several new reconstructions of the LGM have been published and are now available for analysis. With access to the new CMIP5/PMIP3 models - with specific LGM boundary conditions/reconstructions - it is now possible to perform the analysis of equilibrium climate sensitivity in a more rigorous way by constraining the reduced-complexity model with output from the CMIP5/PMIP3 model results.

This project will support a climate modeler from Oregon State University, who will collaborate with a statistician from the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University. Mentoring and training of a postdoctoral researcher is included in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Climate sensitivity is the global average surface warming for a doubling of atmospheric CO2. Its current large uncertainty (1.5-4.5 K, Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2013) hinders more precise estimates of future effects of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. A previous study (Schmittner et al., 2011) had used temperature reconstructions from the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM, 20,000 years ago) with intermediate complexity climate model simulations to estimate climate sensitivity, resulting in a relatively narrow distribution. However, that study did not consider uncertainties in cloud feedbacks. Cloud feedbacks refer to changes in cloud distributions or properties due to warming that cause further (positive feedback) or less (negative feedback) warming. Here we have developed a method to include cloud feedbacks and other uncertainties in the intermediate complexity University of Victoria (UVic) climate model. Intermediate complexity models can be used to estimate climate sensitivity because a large number of simulations is necessary, which cannot be performed by more computationally expensive complex models.

Cloud feedbacks were diagnosed from complex climate models by regressing changes in radiative fluxes to local temperature. This method reproduces well the mangitude a spread between different complex climate models (Ullman and Schmittner, 2017).

We have applied this method in a new ensemble of intermediate complexity climate model simulations, in which we also consider other uncertainties in radiative feedbacks (cloud-free longwave and snow reflectivity), in dust forcing and in atmospheric heat transport. 280 paired simulations of the LGM and future projections have been conducted. However, 77 of those simulations failed mainly because high climate sensitivity models caused a runaway ice-albedo feedback into a "snowball earth". These simulations could not be used for analysis, which made the number of unfailed simulations too small to properly train statistical emulators, which are needed for the probabilistic estimation of climate sensitivity.

However, a preliminary analysis of the results indicates a large increase in the climate sensitivity spread compared with the Schmittner et al. (2011) study. The preliminary estimates use only global mean cooling at the LGM as a constraint and yield a mean of 3 K, a median of 2.5 K, a 66% probability range of 1.6-4.5 K, and a 95% range of 1.3-5.9 K. These ranges are similar to the most recent IPCC estimates.

Currently efforts are underway to re-design and re-run the ensemble, with the goal of having sufficient unfailed simulations for a proper probabilistic estimation of the climate sensitivity.

Broader Impacts

The developed method to use a simplified, computationally efficient, but still spatially explicit, climate model as an emulator for state-of-the-science, complex climate models is likely to impact the field by circumventing computational limitations of large ensemble simulations. These additions to a widely-used climate model will likely benefit the large user community of the UVic model.

Results have been diseminated at different scientific meetings. We have contrinuted to the success of a major paleoclimate conference (XIX INQUA Congress) by organizing a scientific session.

Early career scientist  David Ullman has been trained in climate modeling, statistical methods, and he has gained experiences in teaching. He has presented results at different scientific meetings, attended regular seminars at the College of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences, and networked and collaborated with climate scientists within and outside of CEOAS. He has sucessfully transitioned to a faculty position.

Climate literacy has been fostered by conducting workshops on climate change and ocean acidification for future and current K12 teachers. Schmittner has written an online textbook on climate change for undergraduate students. This textbook will be used in the future by different instructors at Oregon State University and likely beyond. The textbook includes a chapter on paleoclimate.

We have contributed to the international Paleoclimate Model Intercomparison Project (PMIP) by attending meetings and by supporting the working group Past-to-Future.
